The Act aims to consolidate mineral interests in the Little Missouri National Grasslands in North Dakota through the exchange of Federal and private mineral interests to improve land management and environmental protection. Burlington Resources Oil & Gas Company is required to convey all oil and gas rights on specified lands within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Mineral Exchange--November 1995 involves the conveyance of Federal oil and gas rights to Burlington and the exchange of remaining Federal non-oil and gas mineral rights to owners of National Forest System lands. The Act aims to consolidate mineral interests in the Little Missouri National Grasslands in North Dakota through the exchange of Federal and private mineral interests. Burlington Resources Oil & Gas Company must release all leasehold and contractual interests in oil and gas rights to be conveyed to the United States. The values of exchanged interests must be equal, and land use agreements will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will determine that the values of exchanged interests under the Act shall be approximately equal. Burlington will have the right to explore and develop Federally-owned surface lands for oil and gas interests, subject to laws. Surface occupancy rights on federally owned lands for oil and gas rights conveyed to Burlington will be granted. Environmental protection measures will apply to activities on environmentally sensitive lands. The Memorandum of Understanding allows exploration and development on environmentally sensitive National Forest System lands. A map must be provided to the Senate and House committees and made available for public inspection. The Act does not limit the principle of multiple use on these lands. The Act allows for multiple use in the Little Missouri National Grasslands, including outdoor recreation, range, timber, watershed, and fish and wildlife purposes. Federal grazing permits in designated areas shall not be limited as a result of the authorized exchange.
